description: High-level visual and interaction guidelines derived from a light, friendly productivity dashboard UI. This file is intended to guide AI systems to recreate the same look-and-feel across new screens and components in this project.

visual_tone: Light, optimistic and friendly, optimized for day-to-day work tools.
Interface feels airy and low-stress, using generous white space and soft rounded containers.
Use color primarily to highlight actions, states, and important data, not as background fills.
ux_principles: Prioritize clarity and scannability over decoration; content and key actions must be immediately recognizable.
Keep interactions shallow and responsive: avoid complex nesting; prefer inline, contextual actions.
Surface system status (states, counts, warnings) with clear, color-coded chips and badges.
Group related controls into visually distinct blocks to reduce cognitive load.
Favor progressive disclosure: show summaries by default, reveal details via expansion or secondary views.
brand_attributes: Modern, upbeat, and approachable, but still professional enough for workplace tools.
Rounded, soft geometry suggests friendliness and safety.
Colorful accents (especially blue and emerald) project confidence and reliability.

page_background.description: Very light neutral gray or off-white canvas. Must remain bright and low-contrast to let components stand forward.

grid.alignment: left-aligned content within a centered or full-width canvas
grid.description: Use a loose 12-column grid. Containers snap to 4-column or 6-column groupings on desktop. Maintain consistent gutters between sections.

section_structure.middle_region: Primary working area: cards, lists, detail panels.
section_structure.side_region: Optional summaries, secondary actions, or detail panels.
section_structure.bottom_region: Low-importance system messages, calendars, or history.
section_structure.description: Each page should show a clear hierarchy: filters and switches near the top, main content centrally, supporting tools and summaries to the right or bottom.

spacing_usage_guidelines: Use 24–32 px between major sections or cards.
Use 16–24 px padding inside cards and primary panels.
Use 8–12 px gaps between buttons, tags, and inline elements.
Never crowd content: err on the side of slightly more whitespace.
corner_radius_guidelines: Cards and primary panels use 16 px rounded corners.
Buttons and pills use fully rounded geometry (24–999 px radius depending on height).
Inputs and chips use 999 px radius when pill-shaped or 8–12 px when rectangular.

usage: Use no shadows on flat backgrounds or labels.
Use soft shadows on cards and modals to separate them from the page.
Never use heavy or harsh shadows; keep everything subtle and airy.

dividers.description: Use faint dividers and card boundaries to define zones instead of dense borders.

font_family.primary: System UI, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'SF Pro Text', 'Inter', sans-serif
font_family.description: Neutral, geometric sans-serif with good legibility at small sizes. It should feel modern and unbranded.

display_lg.usage: Top-level page titles or hero summaries.

body.usage: Main body copy, descriptions, list items.

caption.usage: Secondary and meta information: timestamps, labels, helper text.

label.usage: Button labels, tags, chips, and status pills.

alignment_rules: Default alignment is left-aligned for all textual content.
Use center alignment only for empty states or standalone messages.
Numbers in metrics may be right-aligned in tables or progress bars when it improves scanning.

color_system.description: Color is used as a vibrant accent over a neutral base. Primary blue drives actions, while semantic colors indicate states and feedback.
usage_guidelines: Keep page and card backgrounds neutral; do not flood large areas with accent colors.
Use primary blue for main call-to-action buttons, key tabs, and highlighted selections.
Use emerald, orange, yellow, and red as semantic state indicators in chips, badges, and tags.
Reserve saturated reds for destructive or high-importance error states only.
Status chips and badges should pair a light background with a strong, legible label color.

iconography.style: Simple, geometric line icons with minimal detail, rounded caps, and consistent stroke weight.
usage_guidelines: Use icons to support labels, not replace them.
Align icons inside circular or rounded-square containers when used as standalone actions.
Maintain consistent icon size across similar components (typically 16–20 px).

hover.buttons: Increase contrast slightly via darker fill or outlined border; apply subtle shadow for raised buttons.
hover.chips: Lighten or darken the background slightly and show clearer outline if needed.
hover.cards: May increase shadow subtly or slightly raise on hover when clickable.

active.buttons: Press state uses slightly darker fill and reduced shadow to imply pressed surface.
active.selection: Selected tabs, toggles, and segments use filled accent backgrounds and bold text.

focus.outline_style: 2 px focus ring around the component using `border/focus` token.
focus.description: Always render focus outlines for keyboard users; never rely solely on color change.

disabled.description: Reduced opacity and removed shadows; maintain visible structure but remove interactivity.

feedback.success: Apply green accents and text for successful actions, ideally in inline banners or chips.
feedback.warning: Use yellow/orange banners or inline messages for soft warnings; avoid alarming reds unless necessary.
feedback.error: Use red tags or banners for critical errors, paired with clear, concise messaging.
feedback.info: Use blue tags or banners for informational notices.

primary.icon_support: Optional left or right icon with 8 px gap.
primary.description: High-emphasis call-to-action button, typically in primary blue.

secondary.description: Neutral outline button used for secondary actions alongside primary CTAs.

ghost.description: Low-emphasis actions in toolbars and dense areas; only minimal background on hover.

tiny.description: Compact buttons used in tag toolbars and card footers; maintain full pill silhouette.

general_guidelines: Always provide clear, action-oriented labels (e.g., 'Start Conversation', 'Join a Plan').
Avoid stacking multiple primary buttons; pair one primary with one or two secondary actions.
Maintain consistent vertical spacing around button groups (typically 16 px from surrounding content).

remove_icon.description: Small circular close icon aligned to the right edge of the chip. It should be understated but clearly tappable.

tag.description: Neutral or semantic label without avatar, used for topics like 'UI Design' or 'Hot Desk'.

person_chip.description: Chip that includes a small circular avatar on the left, used in 'Invite to Conversation' fields.

input_token.description: Chip created from user input inside a tokenized field for tags or recipients.

usage_guidelines: Use chips to summarize status, tags, selected people, and categories inline.
Chips should be easily scannable, with short labels and strong color contrast.
Align chips on a single baseline within an input; when wrapping, maintain a 4–6 px row gap for a tidy grid.
Do not overload a line with too many chips; wrap intelligently or truncate with '+N' indicators.

header.layout: Horizontal: title on the left, meta counts or actions on the right.

usage_guidelines: Use cards to group related information such as conversations, bookings, or benefits.
Always maintain consistent internal padding and spacing between text, buttons, and chips.
Cards should be visually distinct from the background but not overly dark or saturated.

list_item.layout: Avatar or icon on the left, text stack in the middle, status or actions on the right.
list_item.divider_usage: Use subtle dividers between list items where necessary.
list_item.description: Used for people in room, messages, bookings, and other repeated entities.

tabs_and_segmented_controls.style: Rounded pill segments with clear active state using fill and bold label.
usage_guidelines: Use segmented controls for mode switches (e.g., Month / Week / Day).
Limit to 3–5 options for clarity.
Ensure active segment is visually dominant and clearly labeled.

inputs_and_fields.shape: rounded rectangle with 8–12 px corner radius.
inputs_and_fields.description: Used for text entry, search, and tag input fields. Maintain clear focus states and adequate padding.

notifications_and_banners.layout: Full-width or card-width horizontal strips with icon on the left, message in the center, and optional close or action on the right.
notifications_and_banners.description: Use banners to communicate booking constraints, errors, and important notices.

animation.description: Bars should gently animate from 0 to their target value when the card first appears, reinforcing a sense of progress without being distracting.

progress_bar.description: Use thin, rounded progress bars embedded in cards for benefits and quotas. The filled portion uses the primary color, while the remaining portion uses a subtle neutral track.

labeled_progress_row.layout: Single row with label on the left and numeric fraction on the right, with the progress bar directly beneath.
labeled_progress_row.description: Each benefit line shows a human-readable label (e.g., 'All day pass') aligned left and a compact fraction (e.g., '6/10') aligned right. The bar spans the full width under this row.

numeric_summaries.style: Large, bold numbers with compact labels.
numeric_summaries.usage: Counts of people, credits, tickets, and similar metrics.

benefits_panel.role: Compact summary card listing quota-based benefits such as passes or credits, with inline progress indicators and a primary CTA.

header.layout: Title (e.g., 'Benefits (2)') on the left, small 'View all' action on the right.

footer.description: Primary action such as 'Join a Plan' sits below the progress rows, aligned with the left content column.

avatar.stacking: Overlapping circles with slight horizontal offset for groups.
avatar.description: Use avatars to humanize conversations and participants; keep them colorful and diverse.

empty_state_panel.layout: Centered icon or illustration, brief headline, short supporting text, and a single primary CTA.
empty_state_panel.description: Communicates that a user has no messages or bookings; tone should be encouraging and positive.

tokenized_input_field.role: Multi-select field that allows users to add and remove people or tags as tokens inside the input, as seen in 'Invite to Conversation' and 'Tags'.

container.description: The field should appear as a clean pill-like rectangle with a strong outline. On focus, the outline darkens or switches to the primary/focus color.

token_layout.description: Tokens sit on the left, wrapping to a second row if needed. The text cursor appears directly after the last token, with at least 8 px breathing room.

placeholder.behavior: Placeholder text (e.g., 'Type') appears only when there are no tokens or user input.

focused.description: Focus state should be clearly visible with a stronger outline and optional subtle shadow.

disabled.description: Field appears dimmed, tokens cannot be removed, and cursor is hidden.

motion.description: Animations are subtle and functional, supporting clarity rather than drawing attention.
usage_guidelines: Use quick fades and slight slides for modals, dropdowns, and expanding panels.
Avoid large or bouncy animations; keep motion tight and purposeful.
Ensure motion never obstructs core workflows or delays user actions.

contrast: All text and essential icons must meet at least WCAG AA contrast ratios against their backgrounds.
Status chips must use sufficiently dark label text when placed on light colored backgrounds.
hit_targets: Interactive elements should have a minimum target size of 40 x 40 px on desktop.
Increase padding around icons used as buttons to meet this target.
keyboard_and_screen_reader: All interactive components must be reachable and operable via keyboard.
Focus states must be clearly visible and not rely solely on color.
Provide descriptive labels for icons and actions used without visible text.
